Title: We are told to check P/E ratio but how many people know what it means?
Content:
P/E ratio tells you an estimate of how long it would take to recover your investment based on the company's current earnings if all profits were paid out as dividends and the earnings never grew.

Example - if P/E ratio is 10, then it means if you buy entire company, in 10 years, you will recover your entire investment from its profit if companyâ€™s profit remains same. 

And if P/E ratio is 100 then you may not be able to recover your investment in your life time and inflation will also beat you ğŸ˜€.

Investment in companies with high P/E ratio only makes sense if company can grow significantly every year.  PEG ratio can be one of the matrices which can help decide if company is justifying high P/E ratio in such cases.

Title: Monkey and the Stock Market
Content:
The popular Monkey story with valuable lessons for stock market investors.

Youâ€™ll love the story and itâ€™ll be in your minds when you make wrong investments in the stock market.




Once upon a time, a rich man from the city arrived in a village. He announced to the villagers that he would buy Monkeys for â‚¹ 100 each.

The villagers were very happy, after all there were hundreds of Monkeys in a nearby forest.

They caught the Monkeys and got them to the rich man. He bought hundreds of Monkeys and paid â‚¹ 100 for every Monkey the villagers gave him.

They began to make a living out of getting Monkeys from the forest and selling it to the rich man.


Soon, the forest began to run out of monkeys that were easy to catch.

Sensing this, the rich man offers â‚¹ 200 for every monkey. The villagers were ecstatic.

They went back to the forest, set up traps and caught the monkeys and got them to the rich man.

A few days later, the rich man announced he would pay â‚¹ 300 per monkey.

The villagers began climbing trees and risking their lives to catch monkeys and get them to the rich man â€“ who bought them all.

There were no Monkeys left in the forest!

One day, the rich man announced he would like to buy more monkeys â€“ this time for â‚¹ 800 each.

The villagers couldnâ€™t believe this. They were desperately trying to get more monkeys..

Meanwhile, the rich man said he had to go back to the city on some business work and until he returns his manager would deal on his behalf.

Once he left, the villagers were unhappy. They were making quick and easy money from selling monkeys, but the forest no longer had monkeys.

This is when the manager of the rich man stepped in.

He made an offer the villagers could not refuse.

Pointing out to all the monkeys that the rich man had caged. He told the villagers he would sell the monkeys for â‚¹ 400 each.

â€œSell them back to the rich man at â‚¹ 800 each when he comes backâ€ the manager said.

The villagers were over the moon. Buy for 400 and sell for 800 in few days. They had just found the easiest way to double their money.

The villagers collected all their savings and even borrowed money.

There were long queues and within a few hours, almost all the monkeys were sold out.

Unfortunately, their happiness did not last long, as the manager went missing the next day and the rich man never came back.

Many villagers kept the monkeys with them, hoping the rich man would come back. But soon, they lost hope and had to let the monkeys back into the forest as feeding and taking care of the noisy monkeys became extremely difficult.

What does the monkey story on stock market actually mean?
Well, if you havenâ€™t understood the analogy already â€“ this is exactly what happens when you buy low-quality companies in the stock market.

There will be a low-priced stock which no one is interested to buy. A few rich men will suddenly start buying it.

The stock price will rise, because there are suddenly a lot of buyers and very few sellers. Classic case of huge demand and no supply â€“ like the Monkeys in the forest.

The stock gets plenty of coverage on business channels and newspapers. These rich men will also use tricks like sending out bulk SMSes, asking people to buy the shares for huge returns.


New and inexperienced investors, hoping to double and triple their investment, get lured into them.

And finally the big players who had bought the stock early when no one wanted it, sell it back to inexperienced investors at high prices.

Something similar is happening in few companies right at the moment in the stock market!

One fine day, there will be no buyers and only sellers. Those who bought the stock in the final stages of the rise â€“ will lose their entire investment.

They will hold the monkeys (shares) for a few years, hoping the stock price rises back. It doesnâ€™t and the story ends there.

In short, the moral of the stock market story is â€“ invest only in quality companies that are selling products which customers love and use.

Donâ€™t be greedy, there is no quick money in the stock market or in life.

It takes time and effort to become wealthy. And there are no shortcuts!

Title: 15% STCG tax does not apply to most traders.
Content:
The 15% Short-Term Capital Gains (STCG) tax does not apply to most traders. Many traders here are under the false impression that if their profits are short-term, they only have to pay 15% STCG tax. However, this is not correct. There are two ways to tax stock market profits: 


1) via capital gains (STCG, LTCG)
2) via business income taxation as per tax slabs.

Those who:
1) invest via mutual funds
2) invest in shares for the long term
3) invest in shares for the short term but infrequently
4) have a mix of the above

Have to pay using capital gain taxation.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-

On the other hand, those who:
1) trade in F&O
2) trade intraday
3) trade in equity regularly
4) have a mix of the above

Have to show trading as business income and pay taxes according to their tax slabs.

One can use both ways of taxation (like I do), but they have to keep their portfolios separate.

Sources:
1) [Zerodha Varsity](https://zerodha.com/varsity/chapter/taxation-for-traders/)
2) [ClearTax](https://cleartax.in/s/income-tax-on-intraday-trading)

Title: Here is what SEBI has been doing:*
Content:
*Measure:* Gradually raising upfront margin collection from clients to 100 percent. Meaning, brokers needs to ensure that the client pays the entire margin amount before being allowed to trade impact.
*Impact:* This has resulted in clients taking up only positions to the extent possible with their own funds. Also, since brokers can't fund client positions, this has helped reduce overtrading by clients.

*Measure:* Introduction of additional surveillance mechanism (ASM) and graded surveillance mechanism (GSM) on the bourses
*Impact:* This has reduced price manipulation in many mid, small and microcap stocks. While price rigging cannot be done away with totally, it has made it much more tougher for manipulators to cause sharp price moves. By forcing delivery-based transactions in stocks, which have risen sharply, interests of the genuine investors are protected.

*Measure:* Sending notices to brokers for any transaction that may appear suspicious, on the same day itself, seeking details of those trades.
*Impact:* This has helped check instances of circular trading by a set of traders acting in concert. While this measure, too, can't eliminate unfair trading practices altogether, it makes players think twice before trying to indulge in such acts. That is because the probability of being noticed is much higher now.

*Measure:* Reduction in timeline for listing for initial public offering from T+6 to T+3. This means shares must list on the exchange on the third working day after allotment to investors.
*Impact:* This has helped reduce speculation in the grey market over the likely listing price.

*Measure:* Warning AMFI of â€œfrothâ€ in mid and smallcap stocks and nudging it to moderate inflows into small and midcap equity schemes.
*Impact:* It has sent out a clear signal to small investors that valuations have become risky and that need to be more careful of the kind of equity asset they are putting money in. It has also forced mutual funds to become more disciplined in their selection of stocks.
